column1: 2013AGUFM.P54B..05S|2013|Lunar Regolith Maturity Controlled By Ilmenite Content And Micro-Meteor Flux Variability|Schmitt
column2: H. H.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|||P54B|Synthesis of Is/FeO maturity indexes for Apollo 17 regolith samples in the valley of Taurus-Littrow on the Moon indicate that high levels of ilmenite in the samples significantly reduces the level of this indicator of space exposure. The analysis
column3: along with consideration of regolith glass characteristics
column4: also discloses that micro-meteor fluxes vary over geologic time
column5: presumably in response to significant impact events in the Asteroid Belt. Surface samples of ilmenite-poor
column6: silicate-rich regolith have about 80-90% higher maturity indexes than surface samples of ilmenite-rich
column7: basaltic regolith of comparable exposure. For comparison of the history of various regolith exposures to the space environment
column9: the youngest large area stratigraphic unit
column10: provides a specific time horizon. For at least the last ~110 million years
column11: the currently estimated age of the light mantle avalanche
column12: most near surface (upper 1-5cm) regolith has had approximately the same exposure to micro-meteors. The surface of the largely ilmenite-rich basalt fill in the valley has been exposed to space at least as long or possibly 30 million years longer than the light mantle
column13: based on exposure ages for large boulder ejecta in the Camelot cluster of craters. High apparent maturity (Is/FeO >80)
column15: exists only on three types of regolith surfaces: (1) the North Massif apron (e.g.
column20: 72150). Only intermediate to low maturity (Is/FeO <60) has developed in surface regolith overlying high titanium basalt (e.g.
column21: 70181). TiO2/TiO2+FeO ratios provide a good measure of original ilmenite content
column22: ilmenite being the only quantitatively significant titanium-bearing mineral in the regolith. Those ratios for samples showing high and intermediate apparent maturity are about 0.35 and 0.25
column25: 77260) exposed at Shorty Crater as a unit stratigraphically overlying the orange ash
column26: has exceptionally low maturity (8% agglutinates and Is/FeO = 5) but an unusually high amount of "ropy" glass (14-18%). (Ropy glass normally constitutes less than on percent of new Taurus-Littrow regolith. It forms within fresh impact craters as a result of macro-meteor impacts
column27: but the current flux of micro-meteors disaggregates such glass within a million years or less.) The light mantle avalanche deposit protected this ancient regolith unit at Shorty Crater for at up to 90 million years prior to the Shorty impact 14-17 million years ago. A significant micro-meteor flux cannot have existed during the formation of this ancient regolith or it would have a higher maturity index and little or no ropy glass. Variable maturities observed in core samples from elsewhere in the valley of Taurus-Littrow may be the result of either variable mirco-meteor flux or variable exposure during periods of moderate flux or a combination of both.
